title: Imaging and quantification of apical microvilli in the syncytial blastoderm of Drosophila embryos
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Collection, fixation, and de-vitellinization of syncytial Drosophila embryos
Timing: 3–4 h
Place a fresh sucrose-agar plate smeared with fresh yeast paste on the mouth of a cage containing Canton-S flies.
Replace the cage at 25°C and collect the sucrose-agar plate after 2.5 h.
Note: The plate now contains embryos, the majority of which are in the syncytial blastoderm stages.
Pour deionized water into the plate and carefully with the help of a paint brush, dissolve the yeast, taking care not to break the sucrose-agar layer (as shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Note: This dislodges embryos and suspends them in the water-yeast solution.
Carefully pour the contents of the plate into a cell strainer (as shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
Note: The water-yeast mixture passes through the strainer and the embryos remain in the strainer.
Wash the embryos multiple times with deionized water to get rid of any debris.
Pour 5–6 mL of 4% bleach into an empty 60 mm Petri plate. Immerse the cell strainer in bleach for 1–1.5 min such that the embryos are submerged, to remove the chorion, as shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D.
Note: Fly embryos are encased in two semi-transparent membranes - an outer chorion and an inner vitelline envelope, as shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B. These membranes need to be removed for this protocol.
Critical: Avoid increased exposure to bleach as this may damage the embryos. Ensure that the bleach is fresh and unexposed to air and sunlight. Bleach loses its efficiency with time and exposure to air.

To ensure the chorion has been removed, observe the embryos under a stereomicroscope, once before adding bleach and once after the embryos have been soaked in bleach for 1 min. Each embryo possesses a pair of protrusions on the anterior end called the dorsal appendages which are part of the chorion. Before bleaching, the dorsal appendages are intact, whereas after bleaching, they are shed off along with the chorion.
Wash the embryos thrice with deionized water (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E).
Dry them by placing the cell strainer on a piece of soft tissue.
Add 1 mL of n-heptane to a scintillation vial.
Carefully, using a fine paint brush, swipe the embryos up from the walls of the strainer.
Transfer them into the scintillation vial containing n-heptane.
Note: The embryos sink to the bottom of the scintillation vial.
Add a 1: 1 mixture of 4% PFA and n-heptane (1 mL each) to the scintillation vial. 4% PFA and n-heptane are immiscible and separate into two phases - 4% PFA below and n-heptane above.
Critical: The 4% PFA solution should be brought to room temperature before it is added to the scintillation vial to ensure efficient fixation.
The embryos come to rest at the interface of the two liquids, as shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]F.
Place the scintillation vial on a rocker at room temperature for 25 min.
Carefully remove and discard the 4% PFA (bottom) layer of the solution in the scintillation vial.
Remove the n-heptane.
Add fresh n-heptane and incubate the embryos at 4°C for a minimum of 40 min.
Cut rectangular pieces of double-sided tape (∼ 6 cm long) and Whatman filter paper (∼ 6 cm long, and as wide as the double-sided tape).

Remove the plastic covering from one side of the tape and stick the tape to a 60 mm Petri plate along its diameter, as shown in Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]G.
Transfer the embryos and the n-heptane using a 200 μL pipette onto the filter paper rectangle.
Allow the n-heptane to evaporate, leaving the embryos on the filter paper.
Remove the plastic covering on the exposed surface of the tape.
Invert the filter paper rectangle such that the embryos face downwards, and touch it lightly on the sticky surface of the tape. The embryos will get immobilized on the tape.
Pour enough 1× PBS into the Petri plate containing the immobilized embryos so as to submerge the embryos.
Place the Petri plate under a stereomicroscope.
Using a 1 mL insulin syringe needle, poke each embryo at one end of its long axis to rupture its vitelline envelope (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]G).
Give a slight push to each embryo with the needle to release it from its vitelline envelope as shown in the Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1].
Note: The vitelline envelope remains stuck to the tape and the embryo floats in the 1× PBS. Embryos still encased in the vitelline envelope glisten under the light of the stereomicroscope, and are easily distinguished from de-vitellinized embryos. In Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]G, in the inset image, an asterisk marks the embryo that has been de-vitellinized whereas the others are not. If the embryos are soft and disintegrate when touched with the needle, please see troubleshooting[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting] step 2.
Transfer the de-vitellinized embryos in 1× PBS solution into a 0.6 mL microcentrifuge tube. Let the embryos settle at the bottom of the tube.
Without disturbing the embryos, remove the 1× PBS and add 300 μL 0.3% PBST to the tube.

The de-vitellinized embryos can be stored in 0.3% PBST solution for upto 24 h at 4°C.

Staining of microvilli and nuclei in syncytial Drosophila embryos
Timing: 18–20 h
Remove the 0.3% PBST from the microcentrifuge tube containing de-vitellinized embryos.
Add 300 μL of fresh 0.3% PBST.
Wash the embryos in 0.3% PBST for 5 min by placing the tube on a rocker at room temperature.
Allow the tube to stand so that the embryos settle at the bottom. Using a 200 μL pipette, remove the 0.3% PBST carefully without disturbing the embryos.
Add 300 μL of fresh 0.3% PBST and repeat the wash step twice more for a total of 3 washes.
Remove the 0.3% PBST after the last wash.
Add 300 μL of 2% PBTA to the tube.
Incubate the tube on a rocker at room temperature for 1 h for the blocking process.
Allow the tube to stand so that the embryos settle at the bottom. Using a 200 μL pipette, remove the 2% PBTA carefully without disturbing the embryos.
For the primary antibody staining, dilute the primary antibody in fresh 2% PBTA (1:200 for Phospho-Histone H3 in rabbit).
Remove the 2% PBTA used for the blocking step and add the diluted primary antibody solution to the tube containing the embryos.
Incubate on a rocker at 4°C for a minimum of 16 h.
Allow the tube to stand so that the embryos settle at the bottom. Using a 200 μL pipette, remove the primary antibody solution carefully without disturbing the embryos.

Add 300 μL of fresh 0.3% PBST to the tube.
Place the tube on a rocker at room temperature for 5 min. Repeat the wash step twice more for a total of 3 washes.
Dilute Alexa 488 phalloidin (1:100) and Alexa 568-coupled anti-rabbit secondary antibody (1:1,000) in 300 μL of 0.3% PBST.
Allow the tube to stand so that the embryos settle at the bottom. Using a 200 μL pipette, remove the 0.3% PBST carefully without disturbing the embryos.
Add the secondary antibody/dye solution to the tube.
Wrap the microcentrifuge tube in aluminum foil to protect the fluorophores (conjugated to the antibody/dye) from photobleaching.
Incubate the tube on a rocker at room temperature for 1 h.
During the incubation step, thaw an aliquot of Mowiol-DABCO on ice.
Allow the tube containing the embryos to stand so that the embryos settle at the bottom. Using a 200 μL pipette, remove the secondary antibody/dye solution carefully without disturbing the embryos.
Add 300 μL of fresh 0.3% PBST to the tube and place it on a rocker at room temperature for 5 min.
Allow the tube to stand so that the embryos settle at the bottom. Using a 200 μL pipette, remove the 0.3% PBST carefully without disturbing the embryos.
Repeat this wash step twice more for a total of 3 washes.
After removing the 0.3% PBST from the final wash, add 100 μL of fresh 0.3% PBST to the tube.
Transfer the solution with embryos onto a glass slide.
Drain the excess 0.3% PBST by standing the slide on its side.
Space the embryos on the slide by gently pushing them apart from each other using a fine brush.

Excess liquid can be drained out using a thin piece of Whatman filter paper by dabbing the paper lightly at the edges of each of the embryo(s).
Using a cut 1 mL pipette tip, add 2 drops of Mowiol-DABCO solution to the slide.
Carefully place a 22 × 40 mm, #1.5 coverslip on the slide, while avoiding formation of air bubbles and ensuring that the Mowiol-DABCO solution covers the embryos.
Seal the edges of the coverslip with transparent nail polish.
Protect the slide from light by covering it with aluminum foil and allow the nail polish to set for 15 min at room temperature.
Store the slide in an opaque box at 4°C and image them within 1–2 days of preparation to minimize the degradation of fluorophore signal.
Confocal and super-resolution STED imaging to obtain high-resolution images of microvilli
Timing: 3–4 h
Mount the slide on the stage of an inverted TCS SP8 3× microscope containing the super-resolution STED module (Leica Microsystems, Mannheim, Germany) operated by the Leica LAS X software (version 3.5.3).
Load the 100×/1.4 NA oil immersion (refractive index 1.518) objective (Leica HC PL APO CS2-STED WHITE).
Switch to fluorescence mode and toggle to the rhodamine/RHOD (red) filter while looking through the eyepiece.
Move the stage until an embryo becomes visible as an orange glow.
Use the coarse and fine focus knobs to bring the surface of the embryo in focus.
Identify the mitotic stage of the syncytial division cycle based on the phospho-histone H3 label as shown in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B.

Figure 2. Setup for imaging and identification of the cell cycle stage in the syncytial blastoderm embryo

(A) Syncytial Drosophila embryos imaged using an inverted confocal and STED microscope (left). The schematic of the syncytial nuclear cycle (right, magnified inset), showing an apical view and a sagittal view (rotated by 180° to show the apical side on top) at interphase and metaphase. Interphase embryos possess short furrows between cortical nuclei (blue) and long apical microvilli (black) whereas metaphase embryos have long furrows and fewer and shorter microvilli. The dashed line indicates the plane of the membrane shown in the top panel.
(B) Grazing sections of confocal images showing the nuclei, labeled using both phospho-histone H3 (green) and Hoechst 33258 (blue), for each of the mitotic stages (interphase, prophase and metaphase). Cortical F-actin (red) is labeled using Alexa 568 phalloidin at different mitotic stages of a single nuclear division cycle 12. Scale bar: 5 μm.
Critical: Hoechst 33258 cannot be used for labeling samples for super-resolution STED imaging as it might have a negative influence on image quality (background), especially with the 592 nm STED laser. Thus, for super-resolution STED imaging we have used phospho-histone H3 (green) only. We have shown nuclei co-labeled with phospho-histone H3 (green) and Hoechst 33258 (blue) using confocal microscopy in Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B, for each of the mitotic stages (interphase, prophase and metaphase). Interphase nuclei appear as rounded and smooth with non-punctate chromatin in Hoechst, however phospho-histone H3 does not label interphase nuclei at all. Prophase nuclei in both appear as round structures with partially condensed chromatin resembling puncta. Metaphase nuclei in both cease to be rounded and have fully condensed chromatin that appears as thick coiled strands.
Use the laser settings shown in Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for exciting fluorophores and detecting emitted light for confocal imaging to identify the nuclear staining at different cell cycle stages.

Identify the nuclear division cycle number (10–13) based on the area of the apical caps as shown in Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3].

Figure 3. Apical villi images in the syncytial Drosophila blastoderm in interphase and metaphase of nuclear cycles 10–13
(A) Super-resolution STED images of apical actin caps at interphase and metaphase of nuclear cycles 10–13 in the syncytial Drosophila embryo. Scale bar: 5 μm.
(B) Image showing an ROI drawn (yellow) along the boundaries of the apical cap to measure its area using ImageJ. Scale bar: 5 μm.
(C) Quantification of apical cap areas at interphase and metaphase in nuclear division cycles 10–13 in the syncytial Drosophila embryo. Each circle represents the area obtained from individual caps from at least 3 embryos. NC 10, n = 6,3 caps from 2 embryos each, NC 11, n = 9,3 caps from 3 embryos each; NC 12, n = 12,3 caps from 4 embryos each, NC 13, n = 6,3 caps from 2 embryos each. Data are represented as mean + SD, ∗p<0.05, ∗∗p<0.01, and ∗∗∗p<0.001, two-tailed, unpaired Student’s t test.
Apical caps are larger than 240 μm2 during syncytial cycle 10, 120–240 μm2 during syncytial cycle 11, 80–120 μm2 during syncytial cycle 12 and 40–80 μm2 during syncytial cycle 13. Cycle 14 is identified by small caps with area less than 40 μm2.
Move through a few z-planes near the surface of the embryo and find an optical plane which has the greatest number of microvilli in focus.
Set the pinhole size to 1.00 AU and capture a standard confocal image at the optical plane determined above. Use the standard mode with a zoom of 3.5× and scan speed 200 Hz.

To obtain STED images of the microvilli (labeled with Alexa 488 phalloidin), use the 592 nm pulsed depletion laser (Leica Microsystems) at 90% laser power in 2D STED mode.
Keep the gain at 100 and line averaging at 4.
Use the laser settings in Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2] for exciting fluorophores and detecting emitted light for super-resolution STED imaging.

Export the images as 8 bit, 1024 × 1024 TIFF format images with a pixel size of about 30–40 nm.
Deconvolution of images obtained from STED microscopy
Timing: 1–2 h
Deconvolve the images using the STED module on Huygens Professional version 17.04 (Scientific Volume Imaging, Netherlands).
Estimate the average background using the In/near object module by controlling the radius parameter.
Use the Classical Maximum Likelihood Estimation (CMLE) algorithm and set the maximum iterations at 40. Set the Signal to Noise Ratio at 7 and Quality Threshold at 0.1 in the ‘fast’ iteration mode with possible bleaching correction.
Save the deconvolved images as high-quality TIFF images.
